unnormalised: Okay, here's an article on training regimens with the requested specifications:
normalised: Okay, so you want to up your game, eh? Whether you're aiming for the Ranji Trophy like young Rohan from Delhi or just trying to beat your personal best five kilometer time down at Cubbon Park in Bangalore, having a solid training regimen is key. It’s not just about sweating it out; it’s about smart work, not just hard work.

unnormalised: Okay, so you want to up your game, eh? normalised: First off, figure out your goal. Want to bench press one hundred kilogram? Run a marathon in under four hours? Increase your badminton court coverage by twenty square feet? Your training regimen will look completely different based on the answer. Don't just blindly follow what V I R A T Kohli's doing; customize it for yourself!

unnormalised: First off, figure out your goal. Want to bench press 100 kg? Run a marathon in under 4 hours? Increase your badminton court coverage by 20 sq ft? Your training regimen will look completely different based on the answer. Don't just blindly follow what Virat Kohli's doing; customize it for yourself!
normalised: Let's say Priya from Chennai is prepping for a state-level swimming competition. Her regimen probably involves a mix of things. Early morning sessions at the pool (maybe at the S D A T Aquatic Complex), focusing on technique – perfecting that butterfly stroke. Then, there's strength training at the gym, targeting those key muscle groups. Think pull-ups, core work, and leg exercises. And don’t forget the importance of recovery! A good massage, proper hydration, and eight hours of sleep are crucial.

normalised: A structured regimen will often include periodization – breaking the training down into phases. You might have a base-building phase where you're just putting in the kilometers, followed by an intensity phase with speed work and interval training, and then a taper leading up to the competition. It's all about peaking at the right time, like getting your dosas perfectly crisp for a Sunday brunch.

normalised: Don't forget the nutrition aspect! All that training is pointless if you’re fueling yourself with junk. Think balanced meals, lots of protein, and complex carbohydrates. Your coach, or even Doctor Sharma, your family physician, can guide you on a tailored diet plan. Remember, you are what you eat, especially when performance matters!

normalised: Also, consider investing in a good fitness tracker. Monitoring your heart rate, sleep patterns, and activity levels can provide valuable insights and help you fine-tune your regimen. They're not cheap, mind you, maybe around rupees five thousand to rupees fifteen thousand, but they can be worth the investment.

normalised: Finally, consistency is king. Sticking to your regimen, even when you don’t feel like it, is what separates the winners from the also-rans. It's like doing your math homework consistently in school – the results will eventually show. So, put in the work, be patient, and trust the process. And hey, if things get tough, remember why you started in the first place. Good luck!
